Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 07:04PM JoyY wrote: When I was 6 months old I was severely burned over 35% of my body.  The doctors said I wouldn't live. I'm 50 now.  Later after one of my plastic surgeries I got a staff infection in the donor site.  Leg turned black.  The doctors said I would never be able to run.  The doctor's said I wouldn't have much use for my left arm.  After my last surgery at age 13, I have plenty of use.  In fact, Not only did I run and was able to use my arm.  I joined the Army!!  I had several doctors check me out during the physical and after a while, one doctor said.."you don't think there is anything wrong with you do you?"  I said no.  He then said then there is nothing wrong and I served my country. Point is, If a doctor says you can't, start looking for another doctor that says you can.  One that is ready to fight for you and with you and not have you in the grave before you even start fighting.
Posts.Title: Inflammitory Breast Cancer 25% Survival Rate KatFishies4me JoyY

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 10:35PM JoyY wrote: My tumor was very small and my surgeon suggested the lumpectomy with radiation.  He explained that if the margins came back not clear, then I would have another surgery and have more cut out.  Then, if that didn't work, I would go in and have another surgery to remove some more.  If that didn't work then I would have a mastectomy.  I was sitting thinking about all these "if's" and I told my doctor that no, I will go into surgery once....... period.  I had a mastectomy. I was burned as a young baby and my chest had a lot of scars  so,as it was,  more scars didn't mean anything to me.  I have had many, many, many surgeries throughout my life and when that doctor kept saying "and then we would go back and then go back and then go back."....... no.  One surgery was all I was going to let him do.     Like everyone else has said, this decision is an individual decision and there really isn't a right or wrong on whether to go with the lumpectomy or not.  The best thing to do is research ALL options and then make the decision that is best for you.    Just my 2 cents worth :-)
Posts.Title: STANFORD U RECOMMENDS THREE LUMPECTOMIES B4 MASTECTOMY Glendora celia088

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 05:14AM JoyY wrote: Julie,  I have never heard about how having an opphorectomy can cause joint stiffness.  I had a hysterectomy and ovaries removed several years ago and my joints are so stiff, at times it is very hard to walk.  I have thought all along that it is just rheumatoid arthritis.  I never took hormones after my hysterectomy.  Question though, if the hormone therapy to reat breast cancer is to reduce estrogen, then why would someone that has had their ovaries removed need it?  (I'm sorry if this is a stupid question and the answer probably is right in front of me)

Posts.Title: Just wanting to know........ JoyY Jellydonut

Posts.Content: JoyY wrote: 3 weeks ago I went in to have a routine mammogram and am now having surgery Dec 15th for BC.  I have a choice of a lumpectomy with radiation (mammotome) or simple mastectomy.  Actually, the doctor would prefer that I have a lumpectomy.  Anyway, I have done nothing but reading and researching everything I can so I can make the right decision.  I got a copy of my pathology report, but haven't really been able to find anything on the net to help explain it to me.  My doctor keeps telling it's small and don't worry about it, it's nothinhg.  But to me, it's something.  Am I over reacting???  Any way, here is what the report said: Diagnosis:  1.9mm grade 2 infiltrating ductal carcinoma (nottingham 3+2+2+) Microscopic Descrition: On review, a small focus of invasisve ductal cardinoma is identified.  It measures about 1.9mm on the glass slide.  It is composed of nests of large malignant cells showing intermediate grade nuclear features.  The mitotic rate is intermediate.  There is aminimal ducto formation.  Immunohistochemistry for heavy chain myosin confirms the infiltratie natre of the neoplasn. **  can someone put this in english for me????? Thanks Dx 11/18/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Report JoyY wishiwere

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 09:04PM JoyY wrote: I want to thank everyone for the information.  I did go to the main web page and read through the pathology information.  That helped a lot.  When I had my biopsy, the nurse from the doctor's office called to tell me that I didn't have cancer. It was just fat necrosis.  5 days later the doctor himself called to say that the pathologist called him to say that I did have cancer.  I got a copy of my pathology report.  The first pathologist said it was organizing fat necrosis with associated caolcifications.  She then wrote ER/PR and/or Her-2/neu studies are not bing performed onthis case because no carcinoma is present. An second pathgologist looked at this again and did do those test and that is where he found the cancer.  It was imbedded in the fat necrosis.  Can you believe it?  It didn't look like cancer so she didn't test it?????  My doctor said that the lab has two pathologists do the testing.  He said this was very rare and he and the pathologist have been apologizing over and over since last week.  I have an added complicationn due to scars I received from burns when I was six months old.  The only type of radiation I can have is the mammotome.  Doing it on the outside will damage the scars and cause serious wound problems.   I have opted to have a mastectomy.  The doctor said he was going to remove some of the nodes for testing while I'm in surgery and the pathologist is going to look at it then.  Let's just say I'm very, very nervous about the patholgoist testing anything again.  Wishiwere, the pathology report does say 1.9mm.  However, with the first pathologist not doing the job right first time around, I wonder if that is actually correct or not.   Ok, I've rambled and rambled enough.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Report JoyY wishiwere

Posts.Content: JoyY wrote: I should be thankful that my bc was diagnosed in the early stages and if the lymphnodes are not affected I will probably not have to have Chemo.  My mastectomy is next Monday. I should be positive, I should be thankful it's in the early stages and I should be ecstatic. But I'm not.   I have this over whelming sadness in my heart.  This heaviness in my chest to where some times it is hard to breath.  I went to work this morning and could only stay a few hours.  Some one asks me how I am doing and tears well up in my eyes. Than I'm reminded by that person..... I should be positive, I should be thankful it's in the early stages and I should be ecstatic. It's been a month since my routine mammogram and I found out there was an area of concern, which did turn out to be bc.  I'm exhausted, tired, scared, sad... lonley at times.   But then, someone comes up and reminds me I should be positive, I should be thankful it's in the early stages and I should be ecstatic. Am I normal, or am I just feeling sorry for myself?  Dx 11/18/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
